text: <@U2E2H610C|webweb> has joined the channel
Yesterday we published a blog post on _how we do hiring_: <https://pspdfkit.com/blog/2016/hiring-a-distributed-team/>
Might be interesting :+1:
<@U1HLABD1S> people send .doc resumés?
:facepalm:
Indeed :smile:
<@U1HLABD1S> I'm wondering, you have 4-5 facetime interviews. What's the difference between the first and the following ones?
I’ve stopped someone from sending a .bmp CV
Last time we've received a "My CV is attached as PDF. If you can't open the PDF file you can download a free PDF viewer here: [link to acrobat reader]"
Nvm
:troll:
It says what the other interviews are for
Yeah, the second one is usually technical check up.
<@U1HLABD1S> haha
Sometimes there's another technical checkup round after that (but usually not necessary).
<@U0H67LJUA> I count that as a good deed :smile:
Karma+
How can you even make a bmp CV?
You could take a screenshot of a PDF and sign it with Paint
I'll lock it with a password when I send it to you :stuck_out_tongue:
I send .docx files to annoy people :stuck_out_tongue:
I like to zip it recursively
Or use a tar

> Salary expectations. We ask for a rough range to be able to gauge whether this is a non-starter from the beginning.
I hate when companies ask for a range of salary expectation.. because all it is really asking is “what is the lowest amount of money you’ll be willing to work for?”

other than that, I like this blog post <@U1HLABD1S>
Yeah - the salary expectation is fucked up everywhere
just add 3 commas
I guess I’d try and answer it with “I live in [city], I’d like [some reasonable amount], since it isn’t out of the ordinary for developers here."

The issue with salary is, that prior to that we had 2 long running hirings that in the end failed because the applicant was expecting san francisco salaries, which we by all possible means can't provide.
yeah - that’s why you’d provide the range offered
I know how hard it is to get the corp HR to let that information slip
borderline impossible
Well, besides the fact that we can't compete with SF companies salary-wise, we had no real issues with matching salary expectations of applicants and the company.
There are a lot of benefits too, that make up for that.
We can't provide a gym washing service though :smile:
What qualifies as a SF salary?  like $150,000?
I guess, but it probably also depends on taxes and interest (not an expert on intercountry salaries)
A 150k salary in Austria would probably equal 5k after interests and taxes, which in Vienna, is a really, really high salary.
In the end you should at least make up for your salary to make you affordable for the company.
Regarding the gym washing service :stuck_out_tongue:

text: that is ridiculous
<@U16GF1B0F> is it just a text box where they want you to write the salary range and a justification?
<@U09T8SFG8> yes it is
<@U16GF1B0F> copy paste this

I’m more concerned at the moment with talking to you about discovering whether we’re a mutual fit.  If we’re a great fit, then I can be flexible on the numbers with you and you can be flexible on the numbers with me.  If we’re not a great fit, then the numbers are ultimately irrelevant, because your company only hires A players and I only work at roles I would be an A player at.
if they keep insisting keep copy pasting stuff from here <http://www.kalzumeus.com/2012/01/23/salary-negotiation/>

If we’re not a great fit, then the numbers are ultimately irrelevant, because your company only hires A players and I only work at roles I would be an A player at.```

if I am applying and the company is poo, they will lowbal me anyway so no reason to get past the 1st interview if I already know they are poo.

if I am interviewing someone and they are poo, they will either want SF salaries which they are not worth or they will accept peanuts which they are not worth again because i need developers not monkeys
I think it’s Norway where you can look up anyone’s salary at the city’s City Hall..  that would be helpful for negotiations.

<@U0N7D6F50> jobs android, Oslo

<@U09T8SFG8> True, but being the company: how do you upfront filter out those highs and lows upfront? People can look like a perfect match, culturally and technically, but a mismatch from a salary POV

*<https://www.linkedin.com/jobs/view/189162203?trkInfo=searchKeywordString%3AAndroid%2CsearchLocationString%3A%252C%2B%2Cvertical%3Ajobs%2CpageNum%3A1%2Cposition%3A3%2CMSRPsearchId%3A6c583bf7-56f7-45d6-8108-96ff1faed726_1474453099728&refId=6c583bf7-56f7-45d6-8108-96ff1faed726_1474453099728&trk=jobs_jserp_job_listing_text|Product Owner, Native Apps - Oslo, Norway (RQ#752)>*, The Renaissance Network, Inc., Oslo, NO. 
Job Description/Major Responsibilities: As a product owner for Native Apps at itslearning, your main mission is to create and manage ... <http://jobs.ren-network.com|jobs.ren-network.com>
you can use glassdoor and payscale as well, works fairly well
If you spend hours on interviewing a person, until there's the salary negotiation. All those ours could be wasted.
You want to minimize the risk, and remove the pain both for the company, as well as for the applicant (who also invests a lot)
Well if that’s the case, the company should be the one to list their salary range expectations first, before making every applicant spend the time to craft a good application
It would be a lie if you don't have a salary expectation. I guess everybody can say a minimum number (depending on some premises)
<@U1HLABD1S> it'd be easier to just have a transparent pay scale
Even if it's just what you need for a living (if everything else is given by the company)
<@U08GFT5V5> That is very very complicated to have with people from all over the world. If you have a SF citizen, he couldn't afford a mid-range Viennese salary.
On the other hand, living in rural India would make him a king. (just as an example)
There is no definite salary that is given to everybody. Salaries vary based on different aspects: skill, location, experience, deals, etc.
Yeah but isn't that the point of asking upfront?
Person might not be a salary match
That's what we are discussing here. <@U16GF1B0F> probably disagrees with that.
If the interviewee knew your offering for a role, they won't bother applying if it's way less than what they want
But I also see that both parties (applicant and company) should be aware that there might be a mismatch
And that it is beneficial for everybody if that probability can be ruled out as quickly as possible
Without any ulterior motive

In Austria laws require companies to attach a minimum salary to a job position. This minimum salary is provided by the unions (of each industry) and based on the required qualification (intern, normal, management) and experience (junior, normal, senior).
But usually those minimum salaries are only a bureaucratic thing, and not really relevant for your negotiations
Maybe a salary calculator like buffer has would solve problems

<@U1HLABD1S> I just offer market rate if I hire. A candidate should have researched on the current market rate for his skills and he should more or less have the same number in mind that I do. 

Exceptions are in 2 cases: 
1. If the candidate has too big of an idea of himself that he thinks he is worth more than the market rate. 
2. The candidate has more skills than needed therefore he wants more salary which he deserves.

For 1. I fish that out from the interview process and the candidate does not get past round one usually. For 2. I make sure to clarify from the beginning (including the job posting) what type of position this is and what skills we require
like, you know what range to expect

I just think it’d be the most fair/honest approach for the company to list their salary range for the role..   They’re the ones making the investment, and the ones who will be getting a return on that investment (unless the company has profit-sharing).  I almost think it’s not right for a remote company to pay certain employees less than others just because they live somewhere with a lower cost of living…  if they are providing as much value as the others, they should be paid similarly.
also <@U1HLABD1S> your case is quite different since your company is fully remote (as far as I remember). In that case you can have the buffer way which works great
<@U16GF1B0F> I would disagree with that. Cost of living is part of the market rate
Hmm, did not know about the salary calculator from Buffer. I'm definitely checking that out
Thanks for the tip <@U0548MM6B> :nutella:  !
:raised_hands:
The problem is it's a huge waste of time, I ask for 100k, we always end up negotiating down to what the company can afford anyway...
<@U09T8SFG8> then what about “cost of living” + X.. where X is the same for all employees, and “cost of living” is well defined?

>most fair/honest approach for the company to list their salary range for the role
Well yeah, usually listing minmax is what I’d say is great
someone will negotiate more, someone less, someone has more experience, someone less experience
Also, X would have some wiggle room, but nothing huge
If you want to be progressive about hiring, transparency is the way to go IMO

To put the debate down because things are simple. Whoever gives a number first has a negotiating disadvantage, that is a fact. As a candidate I *will not* give my number because I know and have seen how HR, engineer, CEO, whatever will use that number as a low balling practice because it is standard negotiating procedure.

The alternative that I see is both people stating their numbers up front or for the company to state it. I am saying the company because it is way easier for them to know the exact market rate and they are also the ones with the budget, not the candidate.
If the company is decent, then they know what they can get for X amount of money
but the thing is that most companies rely on the fact that candidates do not know their value in order to low ball them
exactly what I was trying to say, but put more clearly
well maybe it isn’t exactly the same, but I can agree with that
^ exactly what I was thinking but wasn't going to say because it's too long and I'm jetlagged
/gif USA USA USA
/gif freedom intensifies
Alright, thanks for the hot discussion everybody! I will definitely forward the feedback to optimize our hiring approach!
<@U16GF1B0F> :nutella:
<@U09T8SFG8> :nutella:
<@U08GFT5V5> :nutella:
<@U1HLABD1S> everything else about the process looks great though.. it’s impressive you can keep the process to ~1 week

I just realized it was for your blog post <@U1HLABD1S> . In any case I wanted to say that most people that I know, when they see a salary range they put a kind of bullshit number since they don't want to get lowballed. That's the issue really, most companies want to lowball people so candidates don't really trust companies enough to put their expected salary ranges.
I find that people that ask for salary upfront typically don’t have a good interview process
:slightly_smiling_face: Since the buffer calculator might be a bit of an overkill for our page, I guess I will recommend we print a wide salary range with the job offering.

If I’m ever asked for a salary upfront, I usually ask for $10-$15K more than market rate. Usually the company will immediately say that is out of their range and give you a number they were thinking which ends up around the market rate, you can either accept or try to ask for a little more or ask for other perks like a phone.
Following that method, I’ve actually had one company in the past offer me more than what I was asking for.
next time I’m changing jobs I’ll take that into account then :smile:

It won’t work for all companies, some will stop talking to you if you ask for a high salary thinking that you won’t be willing to negotiate. Which has happened to me a few times even after I explained that I’m open to discussing the salary.
Since I’m based in NYC it is such an engineers market right now that should I decide to leave my job, I can get a new one in like 3 days.
haha same in london
I think that’s the case in most big western cities
we are lucky as software engineers
/gif i’ve got the power!
<@U0DTEGLJF> could I DM you?
yep :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U1HLABD1S> isn't adding a yearly salary gonna affect the person you pick? It would be best to add the yearly salary estimate to the job offering imo.

<@U061HDV96> I've discussed this with the team. There are several reasons why showing a salary range can leave a bad feeling when applying. We can't give a fixed salary, that always depends on the location, skill, experience (each country has different salaries). Printing a range, e.g. "30k to 150k depending on location, skill, experience" has two affects: 1) people will automatically aim for the upper bound, not their current market value and 2) people who receive a salary in the lower end, will have a bad feeling about not being valued.
That's two things which both from a company's and applicant's POV make no sense.
We're no hiring experts, but that's where we are right now with our thinking process/hiring process.
:slightly_smiling_face:

Those are valid points, though then I wouldn't ask for the salary they desire. I feel that it's not because you got burned once because someone was asking an extraordinary amount of money that you should burn the new hires for it. The focus should be on the person itself and not how much he expects to be paid. I doubt many people will still ask for an unusual salary.
I don't feel that because you're the people hiring us, that you should play it safe. We're both spending our time interviewing when we could be doing something else.
We already had two candidates that have been into a week of interviews, and in the end we had a complete salary mismatch.
That's why we introduced that as part of pre-screening
/gif total mismatch
I’m not meaning to sound like a SJW, but instead of defaulting to “he” for stuff like ^.. why not just use “they”?
yeah i will not go for interview if the salary range is not I am looking for..
It’s more inclusive, and the act of trying to use a gender neutral pronoun helps reinforce the idea for yourself that not all programmers are men
don’t worry, I’m not going to publicly twittershame anyone :stuck_out_tongue:
:smile: Thanks <@U16GF1B0F> I'm going to point that out too.
and using “they” everywhere looks 100% less like you’re trying too hard to be inclusive than by alternating between “he” and “she” awkwardly

<@U061HDV96> What would you recommend us to do? Either we could add a 30k-150k salary range (because that depends on various factors) or we provide a calculator like buffer – that's a neat gadget, but in the end it does not provide any value to me. It's just shows me my estimate market value. I did the calculation (not for Austria though) and came to nearly my salary.
Perhaps ask what they earned previously? It might take some 'stress' off of it.
A lot of candidates would rather not disclose their previous earnings
Ya, I thought so.
we usually ask for CTC
Would be odd to compare with if they should earn more.
Salary is always a hard topic to discuss. On the other hand nobody wants to skip that part :stuck_out_tongue:
In my experience, I tend to get the question very early in most cases, unless the application was by referral or internal since it skips the “foreplay"
Do you ask it for internships btw?
Not so many interns in our company :stuck_out_tongue: We have a 19yo but he's not really considered an intern though pretty fresh.
I wasn't involved in his hiring process either, so no clue.
I really like how GitLab has their hiring manual publicly available: <https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/hiring/>
